ODAMNet

Network visualisation

You can visualise network results using Cytoscape [1]. Here, we describe the steps that we used to create network visualisations.

Active Modules Identification (AMI) network visualisation

On the Active Modules (AM) Identification analysis, several AM are generated. You can visualise them with Cytoscape.

The following Fig. 7 is an example of visualisation:

To create the same visualisation of AM, use the following steps:

  1. Import Network from File: DOMINO_*_activeModulesNetwork.txt

  2. Import Table from File: DOMINO_*_activeModules.txt

  3. Omics Visualizer [2] table from File: DOMINO_*_overlapAMresults4Cytoscape.txt

  4. Manage table connections: link network and the previous table with right identifiers

    • Network: sharedname

    • Table: geneSymbol

  5. Donut Chart Visualisation: Add overlap results using donuts (Use termTitle)

  6. Style:

    • Border Width = 5.0

    • Fill Color = ActiveGenes True #CCCCCC False #FFFFFF

    • Label Font = 20

    • Shape = Ellipse

    • Lock node width and height

    • Size = 50

  7. Filter: Select nodes with overlapSignificant = True

  8. New Network: From Selected Nodes, All Edges

  9. Add legends using Omics Visualizer [2] and Legend Creator [3]

To run AM identification with data extracted from requests, see Use-case 1 or with data provided by user, see Use-case 2.

Random Walk with Restart (RWR) analysis network visualisation

The Random Walk with Restart (RWR) analysis gives in output a score for each node. Theses score are used to selected the most relevant connections between nodes. You can visualise theses connections with Cytoscape.

The following Fig. 8 is an example of visualisation:

To visualise the RWR results using network representation, use the following steps:

  1. Import Network from File: resultsNetwork_useCase1.sif

  2. Import Table from File: multiplex_1.tsv and multiplex_2.tsv

  3. Import Table from File: seeds.4Cytoscape

    • Change column names: node for column 1 and seed for column 2

Tip

How create the seeds.4Cytoscape file ?

awk -F"\t" 'NR==FNR{a[$1]; next} {if($2 in a){print $2"\tTrue"}else{print $2"\tFalse"}}' seeds.txt multiplex_1.tsv > seeds.4Cytoscape

  1. Import Table from File: resultsSelected.txt

    • Change column names: node for column 1, pathways for column 2 and score for column 3

Tip

How create the resultsSelected.txt file ?

The highestScore is the highest score in multiplex_1.tsv file and the gmtFile is the gmt file of pathways of interest.

awk -F"\t" 'NR==FNR{a[$1]=$2;next} {if($3>=highestScore){$3=sprintf("%.6f", $3); print $2"\t"a[$2]"\t"$3}}' gmtFile multiplex_2.tsv > resultsSelected.txt
awk -F"\t" 'NR==FNR{a[$1]=$2; next} {$3=sprintf("%.6f", $3); print $2";"a[$2]";"$3}' phenotype_2022_06_11_diseaseNames.hpoa multiplex_2.tsv | head -11 > resultsSelected.txt

  1. Create two new columns named label as string and keep as boolean in the node table

  2. Filter: Select genes nodes

    • Fill label column with =$name and apply to selected nodes

    • Fill keep column with =$seed and apply to selected nodes

    • Sort by score (decrease) and select the 30th first genes that are not a seed (selected nodes from selected rows)

    • Fill keep column with =True and apply to selected nodes

  3. Filter: Select pathways nodes

    • Fill label column with pathway names (=$pathway)

    • Fill keep column with condition score (=$score>=0.0002083975629882177)

  4. Filter: Select nodes with keep = True

  5. New Network: From Selected Nodes, All Edges

  6. Edit and Remove Duplicate Edges

  7. Style:

Table 1 Network Style

  1. Change network layout (here is yFiles Organic Layout)

To perform a RWR with data extracted from requests, see Use-case 1 or with data provided by user, see Use-case 2.

References

[1] (1,2,3)

Shannon, P., Markiel, A., Ozier, O., Baliga, N. S., Wang, J. T., Ramage, D., … & Ideker, T. (2003). Cytoscape: a software environment for integrated models of biomolecular interaction networks. Genome research, 13(11), 2498-2504.

[2] (1,2,3)

Legeay, M., Doncheva, N. T., Morris, J. H., & Jensen, L. J. (2020). Visualize omics data on networks with Omics Visualizer, a Cytoscape App. F1000Research, 9.

[3]

https://github.com/cytoscape/legend-creator
